purpose: Maxed-out job description analysis with layman's explanations

core_must_have.definition: Skills absolutely required for the job - deal breakers if missing

secondary_nice_to_have.definition: Skills that add value but aren't mandatory

tools_platforms.definition: Specific technologies, software, frameworks, cloud providers

for_each_skill.what_it_does: What problem it solves or what it's used for
for_each_skill.why_here: Why this job needs it (tied to job context)

example_output.what_it_is: A tool that manages and organizes containers (think: shipping containers, but for software)
example_output.what_it_does: Automatically deploys, scales, and keeps applications running smoothly across many servers
example_output.why_here: This company runs their apps in containers, and needs someone to keep that system healthy
example_output.analogy: Like an air traffic controller for software - makes sure everything lands, takes off, and runs on time
example_output.proficiency: Advanced (based on 'architect' and 'manage production' in JD)

checks.name: impossible_experience
checks.example: Asking for 10 years of experience with React (released 2013)

checks.name: contradictory_stack
checks.logic: If multiple competing technologies listed as all required
checks.example: Must know React AND Angular AND Vue

checks.name: unrealistic_scope
checks.logic: If role_level + skill_count + experience_years don't align
checks.example: Junior role requiring 10 skills + 7 years + leadership

checks.name: missing_context
checks.logic: If no team size, project type, or clear deliverables

job_in_plain_english.template: Think of this role as: [simple analogy]. This person will [main responsibility in everyday terms]. They'll work with [team/tools simplified] to [end result the company wants].
job_in_plain_english.example: Think of this role as: the architect and builder for the company's digital infrastructure. This person will design and maintain the 'backbone' that keeps all the company's software running smoothly. They'll work with cloud servers and automation tools to make sure the website and apps never go down.

why_company_needs_this.template: The company needs this because [business problem]. Without this role, [what breaks or slows down]. This position helps [business outcome].
why_company_needs_this.example: The company needs this because they're growing fast and their old systems can't keep up. Without this role, the website crashes during busy times and new features take months to launch. This position helps them scale smoothly and ship updates faster.

sections.background: Where they likely worked before, what roles they held
sections.mindset: How they think and approach problems
sections.experience_range: Years of experience and career stage
sections.day_to_day: What their typical day looks like in this role

example.background: Probably worked at a tech company or startup, maybe as a DevOps Engineer or Site Reliability Engineer. Likely came from a traditional IT background and learned cloud/automation on the job.
example.mindset: They're problem-solvers who like to automate things. Prefer to build systems once properly rather than do manual work repeatedly. Think ahead about what could break.
example.experience_range: 5-8 years total, with at least 2-3 years doing cloud infrastructure work. Not entry-level, but not necessarily a VP either.
example.day_to_day: Half their time monitoring systems and responding to issues. Other half building new infrastructure, writing automation scripts, and improving processes.

what_makes_good_fit.template: Red flags: [what to avoid]. Green flags: [what to look for]. Questions to ask: [how to validate fit].

red_flags: Only knows theory, no hands-on production experience
Can't explain what they built, only lists technologies
green_flags: Has 'battle scars' - can tell war stories about fixing broken systems
Shows progression from junior to senior roles
Mentions specific metrics (reduced downtime by X%, saved $Y)
validation_questions: Tell me about a time when a system you managed went down. What did you do?
Walk me through a complex infrastructure project you built from scratch.
What's your process for deciding between different technical solutions?

recruiting_strategy.where_to_find: Target companies, job boards, communities where these candidates hang out
recruiting_strategy.how_to_reach: What messaging resonates with this type of candidate
recruiting_strategy.what_sells_them: What this candidate type cares about in a job

where_to_find: LinkedIn - search current DevOps Engineers at tech companies
GitHub - find contributors to infrastructure tools
Tech meetups and conferences (KubeCon, AWS re:Invent)
example.how_to_reach: Skip the corporate fluff. Talk about technical challenges, scale, and autonomy. Mention specific tools in the stack.
example.what_sells_them: Interesting technical problems, good work-life balance, learning opportunities, ownership and autonomy, compensation.

boolean_strings.explanation: Search strings for LinkedIn and job boards - I'll explain how to use them

interview_framework.technical_questions: 3 questions per core skill to validate depth
interview_framework.verification_questions: How to validate their claimed achievements

sections: Skill Matrix (table with all skills categorized)

simple_analogy_library.DevOps Engineer: Like a bridge engineer who builds and maintains the roads between the development team and the live product
simple_analogy_library.Data Engineer: Like a plumber who builds pipelines to move data from where it's created to where it's needed
simple_analogy_library.Full Stack Developer: Like a general contractor who can work on both the foundation (backend) and the finishes (frontend) of a house
simple_analogy_library.Cloud Architect: Like a city planner who designs how all the buildings (applications) are laid out and connected in the cloud
simple_analogy_library.Scrum Master: Like a sports team coach who doesn't play but makes sure the team works well together and removes obstacles
